Italian artist and writer Riccardo Sforza, known for his experimental photographs, sculptures, and film, died on December 14. Born in Florence in 1936, Sforza became interested in photography after being sent to a photography workshop by his father. The son soon began taking pictures for the school’s newspaper, the Corriere della Sera, and eventually moved to Milan, where he studied photography at the Scuola Primavera. He then moved to Italy to study photography at the Institute of Photographers of the University of Venice, where he met the American photographer Walter De Maria, and accompanied him to New York, where he traveled to the Utopia, a pastoral camp in the Alps, and to Paris, where he began working with Pierre Cardin and Jean-François Delacroix. Sforza returned to Venice in 1948, but not long after began his career as a painter, for whom he became a founding member. In 1951, he returned to his native Italy, where he remained until his death in 2004.
